For the three-millionth time, Soap wipes the fog off his scope with a damp swipe of his sticky glove. Sure as shit as the sky is blue, it fogs right back up again, no thanks to this god awful climate.

He mutters under his breath, “Jesus Christ, the swamp ass is fuckin’ boggin’ out here.” And sure as shit as Brazil is humid, Ghost answers through the coms,

“That’s attractive.”

Soap snorts in reply. He huffs another breath to push some of the camouflage away from his nose, and adjusts the grip on his sniper rifle. Ugh, his hands are sweating through the gloves.

“This position’s pure shit, L.t. Pretty sure I’m growin’ mold between my toes.”

“Watch out for leeches.”

“Mm, I’ll save one just for you.”

“Eyes up, sergeant,” says Ghost, and gee, Soap sure would love to, if he could fucking see.

Ah, well. Not the first time he’s flown in the blind. The shell plops into the water behind him, a flock of birds take off into the sky, and a body falls into the murky river.

“Target down.”

Ghost’s voice is like butter in his ear. If he was fuckin’ stupid, he’d almost say it sounded like a purr. “Nice shot.” He smugly preens, until Ghost continues, “Hangfire until the rest of the party comes through. I’m on coms with Command.”

Soap internally groans. A bit externally too, if he’s being honest, ‘cause he’s half in the mud, damp and sticky and so fucking ready to get out of this damn rainforest.

“Fucking hell. We still secure?”

“Always, Johnny.”

Some of the anger shifts into light agitation. He feels a bit like a dog that’s been pat on the head. Fuck if Ghost doesn’t know how to work him over by now.

“You owe me a new pair of socks after this.”

There’s a short pause, as if Ghost switched channels to report back to command, before coming through crystal clear in his ear again.

“You wrap this up tight, and I’ll buy you more than a pair of socks.”

Soap laughs quietly.

“Shit, you taking me out to dinner, L.t? Got me kickin’ my feet like a school girl over here.”

Ghost’s tone is flat, deep, and thickly English as always, and yet it still tickles him when he replies,

“Drinks, MacTavish. Get your mind out of the gutter – not looking to get lucky with you.”

A boat comes through the river, but it’s not the search party. Soap holds his breath until the motor passes, then whispers,

“You’re missin’ out. Rumor has it I put out on the first date.”

“Mm, that all? Heard worse rumors than that back in the S.A.S.”

Soap actually perks. It disturbs the water around him, and a fish darts away. He curses lightly, then sinks back to the bank again.

“What rumors?”

“Second boat coming through.”

“Ghost, what rumors?” Soap tries again, in a harsh whisper. He can hear the click through the coms; the safety on Ghost’s gun. “It’s about my sparkling personality and my massive cock, right? Right?”

“Certainly none of those things,” says Ghost. “I don’t kiss and tell my watercooler gossip.”

Soap’s face feels hot.

It wasn’t always this bad. Somehow, what began as innocent, lighthearted banter, has now devolved into notoriously bad flirting. It started in Las Almas all those months ago, and now it’s so heavily engrained into their work relationship, it would almost be weirder if it stopped. The mindless chatter helps him stay calm when the time bomb’s clickin’, but it also keeps him warm, and edgy. Probably not a bad thing either, except for the raging hard-ons.

It's funny because we’re straight. Ha Ha. Funny jokes. Hilarious irony in our secure masculinity.

Riiiight.

“Command says pull the pin. Look alive, Soap.”

“I see it,” Soap grumbles. The boat comes tutting through, Soap trips the wire strung through the trees, and then it’s bye-bye terrorists. At least the explosion is satisfying.

Ghost, ever his guardian devil, takes out a lone straggler that jumped. The shot comes somewhere from the trees. Soap feels like he got the short end of the stick as far as hiding spots go, and he’s about to open his mouth and say so, when Ghost speaks first.

“That’s a good boy, Johnny. Drinks on me.”

The heat cracks through his skull, washes through his gut and down to his miserable feet. Soap barely manages to croak out a response to that.

“M’ not a cheap date, just warning you.”

“Don’t I know it.” A pause, then, “Going to get us patched back to command. Be prepared to report in.”

Also known as, behave, soldier.

There’s short static through the line, until Laswell’s voice comes in clear.

“Bravo 7-1, this is Watcher-1 how copy.”

“Watcher-1, three explosives discharged, seven confirmed dead.”

“Good job, Soap. Load up the bodies and prepare for extraction.”

“Copy,” Soap says, and hears Ghost echo it in his ear.

He crawls out of the mud with a very long and dramatic groan; and far, far away, from the corner of his eye, he sees Ghost climb out of a tree like fucking tarzan.

Their communication line must be closed again, because Ghost says, “Don’t cream yourself before you hit the showers. Can’t blame that one on the mud.”

Soap stops mid moan. He shakes out some of the guck and says, “You’re a dick, sir.”

“You’d like one, wouldn’t you.”

Insubordination be damned, he’s going to have a heart attack and die.

“Oh shut up.”

Ghost doesn’t laugh, like, ever. But he breathes heavily out of his nose (maybe the labor of crawling down from a tree, maybe a chuckle at Soap’s expense). Either way, Soap can pretend his name will stay off the report.

 

It doesn’t.

 

✯✯✯

 

 

If there’s one problem with whatever the hell kind of fucked up comradery they’ve got going on, it’s that the teasing goes full stop as soon as they step foot on base.

It’s all straight backed, chin up, yes sir kinda’ bullshit. All good and proper and cold, like a soldier should be, and sweet Jesus does Soap hate it.

They check in their weapons, sit through debrief, sign all the paperwork and dot their T’s and smudge their I’s and maybe three hours later, Soap is finally scrubbing the river filth out of his hair.

Soap pulls on a clean shirt, and Ghost walks right on by him, not even a fuckin’ glance. Sure, there’s professionalism, and then there’s that good boy that purred in his ears. He’s totally cracked.

Gaz slaps him on the shoulder, and it scares the shit right out of him.

“Hey, good to see the piranhas didn’t nibble off your toes. Can’t afford to lose any more inches, am I right?”

“Fuck off, I’ll give ya a fuckin’ nibble.”

Gaz laughs. He looks happy, probably because he got to sit back at base while the rest of them got dirty.

“C’mon. Price is popping bottles, that’ll cheer you up.”

Soap glances down to the private showers, where Ghost is giving him the cold shoulder. Gaz leads him out with an arm around his neck, so he goes.

 

 

✯✯✯

 

 

Soap is military, so he could sleep on a rusty bed of nails if he had to, but there’s still a noticeable difference between their temporary camps pitched in some random nook n’ cranny of the world, and their base command.

He collapses onto his worn in, delightfully mosquito-free bed. Happy to have his own room again, he lies flat on his back, and stares at the white ceiling.

It’s been radio silence the whole flight home. Just the normal load ins, load outs. He tried to get a word in on the dock, but Ghost got snatched up by command real quick, and Soap sure isn’t looking for trouble that quick off the job.

Truth is, Soap doesn’t know much about Ghost. Besides the missing riddles of his fucked-up past, his chipper personality, and his commitment to hiding away his face; Soap knows him as a reliable teammate, maybe a friend under the right lighting (Ghost would argue otherwise), and yet he hardly understands him at all.

Ghost makes him feel green again, like some recruit that can’t tell his tits from his arse. Not many get to wear the title of ‘living legend’, but some of the privates used to rumor that Ghost isn’t even alive at all.

A load of horse shit, but pretty strange nonetheless. How many dead bodies can you stand over, before you’re no longer human?

Soap feels warm when he thinks about the way it feels to have Ghost on his six. Out in the field, or safe at HQ, Ghost has eyes on anything that dares to breathe. Soap knows what it’s like to be under that microscope. It kinda’ turns him on.

Soap runs his hands down his face and sighs.

I need to get laid.

 

✯✯✯

 

 

The local pub has just enough overstimulation to make him feel scrubbed from the starchy barracks.  

A pool ball clatters into a bucket, people cheer at the sports game above the bar, and Soap stares warily into the bottle of cheap beer he’s drinking. Not his choice, of course, but thanks to the man that’s been checking him out for the last hour.

He’s not really his type; very thin, prestigious, and fashionable. He looks like some trust-fund baby that owns his own start-up – but hey, this close to base, beggars can’t be choosers (and Soap would rather die than sleep with one of the fresh SAS privates – no exaggeration whatsoever).

Well, he’s not ugly, and Soap’s gonna’ sit on something tonight, standards be damned.

“Soo…you travel a lot?” Not-Ugly asks.

“Uh.” Soap mentally maps out the quickest way to cut the small talk and get back to a hotel. At least he can bang his head into the pillows when he’s in doggy. “Well, I –”

A knife slides into the wooden table like butter. Soap tenses for all of three seconds, hand moving for the strap concealed under his belt, before he sees a broad-set figure he could recognize in his sleep. A bar stool screeches unpleasantly as it’s dragged away from another table. Soap holds in a sigh as Ghost takes a heavy seat.

His ‘date’, for lack of a better word, turns in wide-eyed surprise. He opens his mouth as if to argue, but one look at Ghost’s cold, murderous eyes, and the kid is slapping down change and running out the door. It chimes. Soap puffs out a breath.

“Really?”

“Just showing off my new knife,” Ghost says innocently, pulling his blade out clean. He twirls it around in his fingers, before handing it to Soap hilt-first. “You know ‘em?”

Soap glances to the pub door and back.

Okay, he’s not exactly in the closet, but that doesn’t necessarily mean he’s both heels out of it either. Not like sexual preference is an important discussion topic when you’re getting shipped all over the world to do the government’s dirty work; but also, Soap is a little reluctant to make it known. Like maybe, Ghost would stop letting his hair down around him, if he knew.

“Nah.” Soap balances the knife on his finger. It is indeed new. The blade is shiny, sharp, with ridged edges just how Ghost likes it. Good for cutting throats, and even better for torture. “Nice cutter.”

“Thanks. Are you really drinking horse piss?”

Soap turns the Busch bottle around to show that it’s full.

“Not really. You here to buy me that drink?”

“A promise is a promise,” says Ghost. He’s not wearing the balaclava, or the skull plate, but instead a pair of sunglasses and a paper face mask. A baseball cap hides his hair, and Soap is a little bitter about it. Sensing his stare, Ghost removes his glasses, and Soap gets a wonderful view into the stone-cold windows of his stone-cold soul. He leans over to wave at the bartender, “Hey, Maria. One bourbon, one scotch.”

The bartender nods, wiping her hands off on the bar towel. Soap sighs dreamily, and slides his head in his hand.

“You know me so well, dearest.”

Despite his deadpan tone, Ghost’s eyes hold a small shine of humor in them.

“Don’t get used to it. I shouldn’t have to tempt my teammates just to get a job well done.”

Soap grins, “I’m always a job well done. You just like spending time with me.”

Ghost goes hrm, which sounds like a disagreement, but Soap will pretend it’s not. He skillfully plucks the knife back out of Soap’s other hand. He flips it through his fingers, and then it’s gone, like a magic trick. Two scotch glasses are set at the table, and Soap makes a relieved sound.

“Enjoy it while you can,” Ghost says. He grabs his glass with long, tattooed fingers. It almost feels risqué to see his bare hands. Neatly trimmed nails, and scars across his knuckles from one-too many fights. “Laswell is shipping us out again next Monday.”

Soap starts to ask, “Where…?” But he quickly corrects himself at Ghost’s long look. “Ah, not here. Should be sober by then, fuck.”

In one fluid motion, Ghost lifts the bottom of his mask and drinks with the same hand, perfectly hiding his mouth in the meantime, and dragging the mask back over his chin as he pulls away.

“Should be.”

They’ve drank together before. But he always feels weird about it, because Ghost only ever has one round, and Soap can go to the moon and beyond. Something about substance abuse running in the family. Not uncommon around here – but funny, how the usual response is I don’t touch the stuff. Not a man like Ghost. He always has one cigarette, one drink, one bite of the poison apple, just to prove he can bite back harder. He’s the ultimate symbol of willpower. He’s also kind of frightening.

With his head tipped down, the bill of the baseball cap covers his eyes again. Soap doesn’t like that, so he makes an attempt to gain back his attention.

“You going home? A week’s long enough to get away from base, yeah?”

“If I was, I wouldn’t be here.” Ghost tips his head up, and Soap feels relieved to see his gaze again. His eyes look open, but far away. Almost tired. “I’m damn close to giving up my flat in Manchester. Waste of money that is.”

Soap grins, nudging his barstool with the toe of his boot.

“C’mon now, no hot babe back at home waiting for her knight in Riley armor?”

“You’re not funny,” Ghost says, though the look in his eyes says otherwise. “And no time for romance, MacTavish, you know this.”

“Aye, but I mourn all the ladies out there that won’t get to enjoy your charming personality.”

“And my stunning good looks, don’t forget,” Ghost says. Soap gives a surprised laugh, and tops off his scotch. Ghost waves the bartender over for another one, and Soap could just fucking kiss him.

He wishes he saw this side of Ghost more often. But also, he feels strangely privileged to see it now.

“All the more reason to take the mask off.”

Ghost raises an eyebrow; thin, silver, so blonde it’s almost white.

“I don’t see you footin’ the bill. You’re in no position to be making demands.”

Soap feels hot under the collar again. Maybe it’s the rush of real alcohol, or maybe it’s the sound of Ghost muttering in his collied accent.

“I dunno,” Soap shrugs, grinning. “You haven’t seen all my positions yet. I’m pretty flexible.”

It doesn’t earn him a laugh, but Ghost does roll his eyes.

“Stand down, soldier.”

The flirting is all in good fun. Soap finishes his second drink, and they watch the rest of the game on T.V. Ghost rests back against the barstool with his boot hooked on his knee, arms crossed, biceps flexing in his army regulation tee, long-eyelashes blinking neutrally as he looks between the door, and the screen – all the more ignorant to how quickly Soap would crawl under that table and sink to his knees, should he ever ask.

Soap rubs a finger under his nose and sniffles.

Ah, well. Rest in peace his sex life.

You don’t make special forces without missing a few important parts of your brain-bits. Adrenaline-junkies, masochists, pyromaniacs, obsessive compulsive disorders; it’s not personal, just plain math. Nobody with a functioning frontal cortex is going to sneak into an Irani control tower to hijack nuclear codes in the dead of night under risk of a new world war. Well, unless you’re crazy enough to be in the 141.  

Soap sits in the watchtower, rifle between his knees and his night-vision goggles set square on Ghost as he scales a wall in one easy hop. Tall fucker and his long ass legs, Soap totally could have made that jump.

Ghost slits the throat of a guard, and as Soap warns him of a second in the hall, he throws another blade right between their eyes. The body hits concrete, and Soap whistles lowly.

“That was sexy, sir.”

“Yeah? That does it for you?”

“Yup, half-chub at least.”

“Only half? Guess I better step it up.”

“Another guard on your right. Grab ‘em with your legs, I’ll go full mast.”

“I’m not a whore, Johnny.” He snaps their neck, and pulls the body into a bush. His voice comes out slightly labored, and husky. “Although, it sounds like you’re a bit of a masochist.”

The way Ghost says his name is just downright filthy. It rolls off silky, familiar. Almost sweet.

“Who isn’t?”

“I’d hate to see the spank bank you’re keeping.”

Soap bites the corner of his lip, then laughs under his breath.

“Why, afraid you’ll like it?”

Price’s sharp voice comes through the coms like cold water.

“You two are disgusting. Sergeant, Lieutenant – please focus so I can go home and forget this ever happened.”

“I’m focused!” Soap scoffs, offended.

Soap directs his binoculars to Price on the opposite end of the property, where he’s hiding by the fence line.

Ghost trusts Price probably more than he trusts Soap. He’s also the only other living being in the army that has seen any semblance of Ghost’s personality. Price always knows more than he lets on. Probably for the best.

There’s still no movement by the west gate, so he returns to Ghost just in time to watch him stab another artery with perfect execution. Soap wasn’t lying; he is actually half-hard. Something about the way Ghost glides so quietly through a battlefield at night, all skilled instinct and textbook efficiency. That’s sex appeal if Soap has ever seen it. One-hundred percent all organic military cock-fuel.

“I’ve got eyes on target. Soap, how copy.”

“Trigger on your mark, L.t.” Soap pulls the detonator out of his pocket. “Once this blows, be ready to run like hell.” He lifts his binoculars again, this time watching Ghost bend over to plant charges on the concrete wall. “Has anyone ever told you that you have a great ass?”

Price groans, “Jesus, MacTavish.”

He then sees Ghost pause to grab his mic and say, “Yes, actually. In Catania.”

“Tch, figures. Fucking Italians. You know I’ve got an uncle in Rome?”

“Really?”

“Just blow the damn wall,” Price snaps. Soap laughs, and Ghost gives a calm order through the coms. It explodes in a horrible fire of smoke and concrete. He waits for the inevitable;

“Fuck me.” 

“Still alive, L.t?”

“Fortunately for you.”

“Give ‘em hell.”

 

Later, when Price calls him into his quarters to sign the mission statement, he crosses his arms and leans against his desk like a disgruntled father.

“You’ve got issues, son.”

Soap gives a quick signature to his report, and smirks as he hands it over.

“Which one?”

“You like poking bears, or is Ghost just special?”

Soap wants to say something smart, but knows better not to. He shifts slightly, folding his hands behind his back.  

“It’s just a bit of teasing. All in good fun, Captain.”

No one in the 141 is particularly good at sticking to the book (Price included), so Soap doesn’t worry about any misconduct reports. Still, the flat look from Price is just as bad. He puffs smoke out of his cigar, and rolls his eyes.

“I ain’t gonna’ say shit. Just watch yourself.”

Soap hesitates on the way out the door.

“What?”

“Don’t get hurt,” Price corrects. “I don’t think you know what fire you’re playing with.”

Soap shifts uncomfortably, suddenly feeling seen. He tries to laugh it off.

“It’s not like that, sir.”

“Uh huh. Get out of here.”

He sweats a bit when he gets back to his bunk. Ghost walks on by to the mess hall like he’s strolling to the park. Soap is in dire need of some plausible deniability.

 

 

✯✯✯

 

 

“Did it fuck your mum?” Ghost asks.

Soap nearly jumps out of his skin and bones. There’s only one soul on base that’s quiet enough to sneak up on him, and it’s always Simon Riley.  

He steadies the punching bag, and shakes out his sore hand. Ah, he was going a bit hard, but they’re still another week out until they get a break, and Soap’s got more pent-up frustration than a shaken coke bottle.

Ghost bangs his fist against the metal support rod, and after a loud clunk, Soap realizes he had punched the peg out of alignment. He runs his hand across his damp mohawk and laughs.

“Impressed?”

“Concerned. You better keep up tomorrow.”

“Mahh, I’ll be fine. Just burning energy, sir.”

Ghost hums neutrally, and flings his sweat towel over his broad shoulder. Soap always tries to avoid eye contact in the gym mirror while he’s lifting weights, because Ghost’s shirt always sticks to his stomach like something out of magic mike. The lad’s fuckin’ shredded, and even just looking at him now, Soap suddenly has a whole new wave of vigor to burn off. There’s a gap between his balaclava and his army green shirt, and Soap wants to lick the sweat out of his shiny collarbones.

Nova speaks up from the weight rack, setting down the bar and rolling out her shoulder.

“Hey, MacTavish. I’ll spar with ya.”

She’s a new transfer to the base; highly decorated, and pretty damn hot. Soap looks her up and down, weighs his chances, and decides what the hell.

“No,” Ghost says, before Soap can even formulate an answer. He grabs him strongly by the shoulder, and Soap’s eyes nearly bug out of his head. “I’ll wear him out.”

Double entendres aside, Soap blanches. He jerks his head up to meet Ghost’s sharp gaze – his grey eyes squint in a challenge, and Soap feels his heart sink to his knees. He doesn’t look amused. Nova submits almost immediately, fleeing back to the squat rack to avoid Ghost’s killer glare. Soap’s stomach starts to cramp.

Ah. I’m going to die.

A hell of a way to go. Soap pats him on the back and starts towards the ring, teasing, “Think you can keep up? I can go all night.” He really is a Masochist. Ghost cracks his knuckles with a single squeeze of his palm.

“Don’t complain if you’re sore tomorrow.”

His mind is so far in the gutter, he might as well board his ticket to hell. Ghost is dressed as casual as Soap will ever see him; grey trackies, a plain balaclava, and dog tags hanging out of his shirt. It’s a true testament to Soap’s willpower that he manages to keep his eyes above the waist while Ghost swings a leg into the ring.

 

Soap gets his ass handed to him. He manages to get a few good hits in, and a kick strong enough for Ghost to grunt from the impact (despite it feeling like he’s smacking a concrete wall).

He goes to bed with the same problem he woke up with.

 

 

✯✯✯

 

 

Some American idiot slipped the wrong file into the wrong hands, so Price’s squad is called in to do the dirty work.

“Must be nice to throw money at every inconvenient problem,” Soap mutters. His semi-auto is pointed down a long, dimly lit hallway. “Why follow the rules when you can pay someone to clean up your mess...”

“Isn’t that where you get the name?”

Ghost’s voice is much closer than usual. He’s looking up something on the satellite, a hand resting on Soap’s shoulder while he punches in numbers. At the end of the day, they still work best together, so in lieu of results, command keeps sending them.

“Wouldn’t you like to know.”

Gaz buzzes in.

“The room is clear. Soap, Ghost, you’re good to move.”

“Copy.”

Ghost pockets the touchpad and raises his gun again, and together they move down the hall. The building is full of reflective glass, each shadow making him jumpy. Something about this mission already stinks to high hell, and they all know it. Together, Soap and Ghost clear rooms until they find the office they’re looking for.

“We’ve got thirty minutes until security is back online,” Ghost whispers. He holds the door open, and Soap tucks inside. “Red file, zed alpha–”

“I know what I’m lookin’ for,” Soap snaps. He uses the false thumbprint to start pulling open file cabinets. “Sheesh. You’d think a private investigator would be living a little less lavishly.”

Ghost props his shoulder in the doorway, his rifle lowered. He checks the hall every so often, but turns his body to face Soap.

“They’re brains for hire, not so different than us.”

“Different paycheck, I’m betting,” Soap grumbles. “Steamin’ hell, where is this thing…”

He can hear the smirk on Ghost’s face as he mutters, “You need me to read for you, too? Needy little thing.”

A tingle runs down the back of his spine. Soap uses every cell of discipline not to shudder. He yanks open another file cabinet in a huff.

“If I didn’t know better, I’d say you like to feel needed. The way you’re always running to Price’s office, looking for a bone.”

“It’s called being responsible, MacTavish, you should try it sometime.”

The mood feels different; bickering like this in the same room, rather than over the coms. Soap’s thumb runs down an alphabetical file until he finds the section he’s looking for.

“Almost got it!”

“Fuck me,” says Ghost.

“Not sure now’s the time –”

“No, I mean fuck,” Ghost hisses. He slams the door shut and begins to yank down all the window shudders. “Someone’s coming!”

“Ghost! Soap! Two civilians headed your way, fast. Do not kill, I repeat, do not kill!”

“I fucking see that!” 

“Shit shit shit!” Soap slams the cabinet shut, and starts to run his hand along the window for a lock. “Ghost, we’re sixty floors up!”

Talking starts to echo from the hall. Soap looks up for any sign of ductwork. He nearly has his neck snapped off when Ghost grabs him by the strap of his vest, and yanks him into a supply closet.

They fall on top of each other. Soap slaps a hand against the wall to keep his gun from ramming into Ghost’s face. Ghost slams the door shut just in time, because the footsteps grow louder.

“— then I…huh. I don’t remember leaving this light on.”

“Who cares, just take your pants off.”

Ohh shit.

Soap sucks in a breath. He searches for Ghost’s eyes in the dark, and sees him staring back, equally wide-eyed. They’re both trying to catch their breath, both trying to stay quiet, while the sound of a belt buckle rings out like a gunshot.

One male, one female. Light streams under the crack of the closet door. Soap hopes the guy’s a quickie, because this closet is three-feet wide at best, and he already knows his thighs are going to cramp from the awkward position, hovered over Ghost’s lap like this.

Ghost breathes in, then out, like he’s getting himself under control. Soap respects his mental fortitude, because he’s definitely on the edge of freaking out. Their cargo packs are pressed together. Soap makes a signal with his hand, and Ghost nods. Through teamwork, Ghost is able to take the gun out of his hand, and position it somewhere by his thigh, so it won’t clatter when Soap readjusts himself against the wall. It takes some of the strain off.

“— mm, fuuck. Ah! Ah, Annie…”

Soap squeezes his eyes shut in frustration. This sucks.

He can feel something by his foot, maybe a mop or a bucket. One bad move, and they’re fucked. Ghost continues to breathe steadily against him, and when a hand squeezes his arm, he realizes Ghost is trying to keep him calm.

The moaning gets louder through the door. Office supplies clatter, and the woman gasps.

Soap’s nose is right by Ghost’s ear. He can smell the sweat on him, the military regulated detergent they use in the laundry, and a cologne that’s gone old. He smells like fucking sex, and he’s in his lap, and Soap’s brain chooses that lovely moment to remind him how long it’s been since he got laid.

He grinds his teeth so they squeak. Ghost tips his head slightly, and whispers so, so quietly, it feels like a prayer.

“Lean on me, Soap. I’ve got you.”

Ghost is flat on his butt. The angle is probably none too comfortable for his long ass legs, but at least he’s not in a half squat. Again, Ghost encourages him to push more weight on him. He settles for his shoulder, instead of his lap.

“Oh! Oh! Oh my god!”

Skin slaps skin. Soap’s stomach curls with the horrifying realization that he’s getting hard.

He wills it away with every random thought. Blisters on his feet. Cramping in his arm. The discomfort of the utility straps rubbing into his thighs. His feet are going numb. Sweat is running down his temple. His pants feel tight, fuck fuck fuck.

Ghost keeps a careful grip on his arm to hold him steady. His pale eyelashes catch in the light streaming through the crack in the door. Soap sees down the back of his neck, where a shoulder tattoo peeks under his shirt collar. Soap physically feels his cock start to fill.

The moaning is loud and obscene and honestly, a little over-dramatic for his tastes. She’s totally faking an orgasm, and the guy is falling for it. More noise, a bang of the cabinet as they change positions. His erection rests uncomfortably against his zipper, and he hopes to all fuck that Ghost can’t see in the dark.

Soap throws on cargos and a hoodie, and takes Ghost down to the garage, where his girl is sleeping under a cover. She purrs right to life, like he never left. Soap gets Ghost on the back of her, warms up the engine – and realizes how happy he is that they got the hell out of HQ.

Ghost holds him loosely on one side of his waist, his other hand gripping the back of his bike, and it's no surprise that the helmet suits him so well. Soap takes them far out of town; to the country roads, and the rolling hills he used to play on. Eventually, Ghost's hand sneaks to his inner thigh and grabs him there, and it makes Soap smile under his visor. 

It instills a little piece of humanity into their souls. For when they’re knee deep in the mud, stepping over the dearly departed, and carving sins into flesh – they’ll have this moment to remember. Just for them.

 

 

✯✯✯

 

“The prodigal son returns,” Soap says, lifting his hand as he steps into the common area. “Please, hold your applause.”

Laswell breathes a laugh out of her nose, and swings back her whiskey. Price lowers his feet off the table only so Soap can scooch in on the couch and grab a drink. He kicks his feet right back up.

“I already have a favorite child, and it is clearly Gaz.”

Soap scoffs, while Gaz makes a peace sign. “I’m offended, sir. You’ve known him half the time.”

“And yet I like him twice as much,” Price counters. He slaps a palm on the top of Gaz’s head, who blinks rapidly through the alcoholic haze. “I would’ve birthed him myself, If I could.”

“Oh, gross.”

“You’re drunk,” Ghost says, not taking a seat, but accepting the whiskey from Laswell.

“It’s our last chance before half the squad comes back tomorrow,” Price grumbles. “You’re a day early, by the way.”

Soap purrs, “We just missed you too much sir.”

“Ugh.”

“Got bored of the sex already?” Gaz teases.

“Nah, but a few more days I’d be more stuffed than a—”

“Don’t!” Price shouts. “Do not tell me. Open your mouth and you’ll be scrubbing latrines, Sergeant.”

“Soap,” Ghost warns.

Soap surrenders, “Fine, fine. Just answering the question.” 

“Woah, you two…?” Laswell looks between Soap and Ghost. She’s not disgusted, but genuinely surprised. “Clearly I missed a few steps.”

“Consider yourself lucky,” Gaz mumbles. “Gonna’ need a lobotomy to forget the things I’ve heard.”

Ghost puts a firm end to the conversation. “Change the topic or die.” Thing is, that threat isn’t even empty. A few bottles clink around while more rounds are poured.

“We demoed the old watchtower while you were gone,” Gaz says quickly. “Y’know, to make room for that new training ground.”

Soap’s heart breaks in two. He leans over to grab at Gaz, but Price holds him back with a lazy palm.

“You blootered bastard, you blew shit up without me?!”

“No goddamn loyalty around here. I’m calling Alejandro and moving to Mexico.”

Soap makes eye contact with Ghost. There’s no expression from the mask, but his eyes look…alive. Almost happy.

Soap grins, and kicks up his feet by Price.

“Got me there, Captain.”

 

✯✯✯

 

 

If there was a downside to their little vacation, it would be that Soap now has significantly less leverage out in the field, and it’s not for the reasons you’d think.

“You bung this up, you’re sleeping in your own bunk tonight.”

“I feel like,” Soap reloads his rifle, and takes out the sniper in the watchtower. “The crime doesn’t fit the punishment here, L.t.”

Ghost's soothing voice is a welcome comfort to his ears, even when he's angry. 

“Just get out alive. If I have to come rescue you, you’re going to find out what real punishment is.”

Soap grins, adjusting his scope. This whole job is less than ideal, but he can count his blessings that he’s not in the sun, and he’s not in the damn rainforest. A bit of snow just feels like home.

“That sounds hot.”

“Really? You wanna’ get spanked?”

Soap moans a little.

“Wait, hold on, I gotta’ take down the rest of these towers before I get hard.”

Ghost sounds like he doesn’t know whether to laugh, or cry.

“You are unbelievable.”

“Heh. All snipers down. I’m moving in.”

“Wait. Look up, love.”

Soap does, just in time to watch a giant hole blow in the wall of the base, like it was hit with a rocket launcher. The fire explodes in hues of red and orange, soot catching in the snow flurries like grey little crystals. The light reflects in Soap’s eyes as he gasps, happily.

“Was that for me?”

“Affirmative. Merry Christmas, Johnny.”

Soap laughs, picking himself up out of the snow, and bracing his rifle on his shoulder.

“Fucking beautiful, sir. I could kiss you.”

“Save that for later. See you on the other side.”

Soap meets him in a world of ice, fire and ash. Bullets flying, helicopters whirring, their kneepads scraping the ground as they slide behind rubble and chuck grenades into a raging storm – there’s nothing more romantic in their hell-risen world.

 

It's the thrill of addiction.
